text:
GRUENE Sample local honey wine at Texas mead event Honey wine lovers can get their fill when eight meaderies from across the state gather Sept. 19 in Gruene for Texas Mead Fest 2015.
Visitors will enjoy live music, food trucks, honey tastings, a homebrew competition and more.
The fourth annual event will feature tastings for those 21 and older.
The popularity of the alcoholic drink, which is made by fermenting honey, has grown dramatically in recent years with new meaderies continuing to open.
Admission is free. Eight tastings and a glass may be purchased in advance for $20 or at the gate for $25.
Hours are 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. at Rockin’ R River Rides, 1405 Gruene Road.
Contact: texasmead.org/mead-fest.aspx
LAS CRUCES, N.M. Bacon, bourbon, beer make for a yummy feast of flavors When bacon is included at a fest, do you really need anything else? Maybe not. But attendees at the second annual Beer, Bacon & Bourbon Festival will have much more in store.
The event is 5-11 p.m. Sept. 19 at the New Mexico Farm and Ranch Heritage Museum, 4100 Dripping Springs Road.
There will be more than 160 craft beers and bourbons available, plus loads of bacon. Local restaurants will offer foods to sample, including mini hotdogs with bacon relish; bacon macaroni and cheese; maple bacon donuts; and chocolate covered bacon.
Live music and family-friendly entertainment will also be included.
Tickets are $20 per person and include five 1-ounce samples of beer and five .25-ounce samples of bourbon.
Contact: beerbaconbourbonfest.com
ABILENE Book festival offers up-close time with authors Abilene, which was recently named the Storybook Capital of Texas, will celebrate all things literary during the 15th annual West Texas Book Festival.
The event, Sept. 21-26, will feature presentations by local and regional authors, book signings, a black-tie Cookbook Gala and a Boots & Books Luncheon. A special publishing workshop will help aspiring authors get started on their own books.
Attendees may want to get in town early for a pre-festival visit from 11:45 a.m. to 1 p.m. Sept. 18 with H.G. “Buzz” Bissinger, author of several books including Friday Night Lights: A Town, a Team, and a Dream . Bissinger has won the Pulitzer Prize, the Livingston Award, the American Bar Association Silver Gavel Award and the National Headliners Award, among others.
Copies of his works will be available for purchase at the program.
Contact: abilenetx.com/apl; 325-676-6025
WINTER PARK, COLO. Change of season is a prime time for getaway deals Going back to school doesn’t mean the fun has to end. Retirees, empty-nesters and families can find off-season deals in Winter Park, Colo. Some ideas for an autumn trip to the area include:
Bike riding. September is Try a New Trail Month, and the area offers 600-plus miles to explore. Local favorites include Meadow Creek Reservoir (Junco Lake) and the James Peak Protection Area. Download a map for more trails or visit the Winter Park Information Center at 78841 U.S. Highway 40 and get in-person route advice.
Scenic drives. Want to see the season’s changing colors? The famous Trail Ridge Road in Rocky Mountain National Park, Corona Pass up the Continental Divide, and Willow Creek Pass are just a few options. Visitor tip: Be on the lookout for elk bugling during their annual breeding season.
Golfing. Four local course options are Pole Creek, Grand Elk, Granby Ranch and Grand Lake.
Fishing. Choose a spot on the Colorado or Fraser rivers, or on any of the numerous lakes and streams nearby.
Contact: playwinterpark.com/winter-park-deals.htm ; mtbcapitalusa.com/trail-map
